questions.text: A patient undergoes lumbar puncture for the evaluation of suspected meningitis. Two days later, he develops a severe headache that worsens when he sits or stands and improves when lying down. He has no fever, neck stiffness, or neurological deficits. His headache persists despite conservative measures such as bed rest and analgesics. What is the next appropriate treatment?

A 40-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of progressive weakness, initially localized to his legs but now involving the arms. He reports increased difficulty with tasks such as buttoning his shirt and climbing stairs, along with episodes of fatigue during minimal exertion. He also describes a tingling sensation in his fingers and has experienced mild fever and generalized malaise over the past week. On examination, he demonstrates significant weakness in all four extremities, reduced muscle tone, and absent deep tendon reflexes. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis

questions.correct_answer: A. Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid analysis
questions.explanation:
Category

Findings

Lumbar Puncture
  • CSF protein: 100-1000 mg/dL
  • Elevated CSF protein but normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Study Timing
  • Normal CSF findings (<48 hours)
  • Maximum rise of protein seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing
  • Prolonged F-wave latencies
    • Earliest finding in AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy)

Criteria

Description

Flaccid Bilateral Weakness

Weakness of limbs (flaccid).

Areflexia

Areflexia is present in areas of weakness.

CytoAlbuminologic dissociation

Elevated CSF protein with normal WBC count.

Monophasic Illness

Symptoms develop over 12 hours to 28 days.

Electrodiagnostic

Electrodiagnostic findings are consistent with demyelination.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with progressive memory loss, difficulty in performing daily activities, and mood changes. His family notes that he often repeats the same questions and becomes easily confused. Neurological examination reveals no focal deficits, but cognitive testing indicates significant impairment in memory and language skills. What is the possible neurotransmitter status for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased Acetylcholine, decreased Norepinephrine, decreased Serotonin

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased Acetylcholine, decreased Norepinephrine, decreased Serotonin

options.label: C
options.text: Normal Acetylcholine, increased Norepinephrine, normal Serotonin

options.label: D
options.text: Increased Acetylcholine, increased Norepinephrine, decreased Serotonin

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased Acetylcholine, decreased Norepinephrine, decreased Serotonin
questions.explanation:
Neurotransmitter

Location of Synthesis

Decreased ACh

Nucleus basalis of Meynert (forebrain)

Decreased Norepinephrine

Locus coeruleus (pons)

Decreased Serotonin

Dorsal raphe (brainstem)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with Down syndrome is being monitored for cognitive decline due to his increased risk for Alzheimer's disease. Why is this patient at a higher risk for developing Alzheimer's disease?

options.label: D
options.text: Release of pro-inflammatory cytokines and promoting insulin resistance

questions.correct_answer: B. Overexpression of the APP gene
questions.explanation:
Chromosome 1

Presenilin 2 gene defective

Chromosome 14

Presenilin 1 gene defective (Option A ruled out)

Chromosome 19

ApoE gene

ApoE4 allele: Higher risk of developing sporadic Alzheimer's disease (Option C ruled out)

ApoE2 allele: Low risk

Chromosome 21

The amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene

Alzheimer's Disease in Down syndrome (extra copy of chromosome 21 leads to overexpression of the APP gene) (Option B)

Early-age-of-onset familial AD

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults?

Identify the correct statements on CNS tumours. Calcifications are found in Meningioma and Oligodendroglioma. Rathke’s cyst and Craniopharyngioma are present as suprasellar masses. Meningioma and Glioblastoma multiforme never cross the midline. Giant cell Astrocytoma and Ependymoma occur as Intraventricular tumours. Schwannoma is an important Cerebello-pontine angle tumour. Metastatic lesions are never present in the suprasellar area.
questions.explanation:
Important Facts on CNS Tumours

Sellar/ Suprasellar Tumours

(Statement 2 & Statement 6)

Cerebello-Pontine Angle Tumors

(Statement 5)
  • Pituitary Adenoma
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Rathke’s cyst
  • Meningioma (Presence of Dural tail)
  • Schwannoma
  • Dermoid
  • Germinoma
  • Metastasis

  • Arachnoid cyst
  • Paraganglioma
  • Metastasis

Calcifications in CNS Tumours

(Statement 1)

(Statement 3)

  • Chordoma

  • Multiple Sclerosis

Tumour mimics

(Statement 4)

questions.text: A 40 y/o man with a known brain tumour has recently undergone radiation therapy. During a follow-up visit, his doctor ordered imaging studies to evaluate the tumour. The physician wants to determine whether the changes observed on the imaging are due to tumour progression or necrosis resulting from treatment. Which imaging technique can help differentiate between the two?

Match the following syndromes with their most commonly seen brain tumours respectively. 1. Von Hippel Landau a) Bilateral vestibular schwannomas 2. Tuberous sclerosis b) Glioma 3. Neurofibromatosis 2 c) Hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum 4. Li Fraumeni Syndrome d) Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma
questions.explanation:
Syndrome

Associated Tumours

Cowden's syndrome

Dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma (Lhermitte-Duclos disease), meningioma, astrocytoma, breast, endometrial, thyroid cancer, trichilemmomas

Gardner's syndrome

Medulloblastoma, glioblastoma, craniopharyngioma, familial polyposis, multiple osteomas, skin and soft tissue tumours

Li-Fraumeni syndrome

Gliomas, medulloblastomas, sarcomas, breast cancer, leukaemia, and others

Lynch syndrome

Glioblastomas and other gliomas

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (Wermer's syndrome)

Pituitary adenoma, malignant schwannoma and pancreatic islet cell tumours

NF1

Schwannomas, astrocytomas, optic nerve gliomas, meningiomas, neurofibromas, neurofibrosarcomas, and others

NF2

Bilateral vestibular schwannomas, astrocytomas, multiple meningiomas, ependymomas

Tuberous Sclerosis (Bourneville disease)

Subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, ependymomas, glioma, ganglioneuroma, hamartoma

Turcot syndrome

Gliomas, medulloblastomas

Von Hippel Landau

Hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum, retinal angiomas, renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, pancreatic tumours and cysts, endolymphatic sac tumours of the middle ear

questions.text: A 45 y/o man presents with fever, a headache, and focal neurological deficits on the right side. He had dental surgery two weeks ago. CT shows a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding oedema in the left temporal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Brain Tumor and Brain Abscess
 

Brain Tumour

Brain Abscess

Cause

Abnormal growth of cells in the brain or meninges.

Localised collection of pus due to infection.

Symptoms

Headaches, nausea, and vomiting due to raised intracranial pressure.

Seizures and gradual neurological deficits.

Headaches, fever (in about half of cases), focal deficits, and sometimes seizures.

Diagnosis

MRI and CT scan

Biopsy confirms the type and grade

MRI is preferred, CT-guided aspiration identifies the infectious agent.

Treatment

Surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy.

High-dose intravenous antibiotics and surgical drainage.

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with lethargy, poor feeding, irritability, and a bulging fontanelle. Born prematurely at 34 weeks with low birth weight, a lumbar puncture reveals cloudy cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with high white blood cell count, decreased glucose, and elevated protein levels. Which is not a causative factor for this infant's condition?
questions.explanation:
Bacterial meningitis in neonates and children

Common Causes by Age Group

Neonates

Pre-school Children

Older Children
  • Escherichia coli (gram-negative bacilli)
  • Group B streptococci
  • Listeria monocytogenes (Option A, B and D ruled out)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae

Clinical Features

Lethargy, fever, hypothermia, seizure, headache, stiff neck, irritability, drowsiness, and vomiting.

Diagnosis

Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis):

  • Cloudy CSF with high white blood cell count (neutrophils)
  • Elevated protein, decreased glucose

Gram stain or culture reveals bacteria

Treatment

Empirical antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics started immediately

Targeted antibiotics: Based on causative bacteria

Adjunctive glucocorticoid therapy.

Complications

Hearing loss (common with H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae), seizures, memory impairment, decreased intellectual function, hydrocephalus, sepsis, and risk of death

Prevention

Vaccination: Against H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis

Chemoprophylaxis: Prophylactic antibiotics for close contacts of meningococcal meningitis cases.

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: B. Lymphocytic pleocytosis with normal glucose levels
questions.explanation:
HSV Encephalitis Diagnosis

CSF Analysis

PCR

Neuroimaging and EEG

  • Shows lymphocytic pleocytosis (increased lymphocytes).
  • Normal glucose levels.
  • Slightly elevated protein concentration.

CSF PCR for HSV is highly sensitive (96%) and specific (99%) for confirming diagnosis.
  • MRI is preferred for early detection of HSV encephalitis. Characteristic lesions appear on T2-weighted and diffusion-weighted MRI, affecting the orbitofrontal and temporal lobes.
  • EEG may show periodic slow-wave activity in the temporal lobes, indicative of HSV encephalitis.

questions.text: A 45 y/o male with a history of HIV infection presents to the ED with headache, fever, photophobia, and neck stiffness. His CD4 count is 80 cells/mm³. Lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, low glucose, and elevated protein levels. India ink staining of the cerebrospinal fluid showed the following picture. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Causes
  • Cryptococcus neoformans (most common)
  • Candida
  • Histoplasma
  • Blastomyces
  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix

Risk factors

Immunocompromised patients

Clinical features
  • Headache
  • Altered mental status, lethargy
  • Fever
  • Neck stiffness
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Investigations
  • Lumbar Puncture: Low glucose and high protein levels. White cell count can be normal or higher than 20 microL and have a lymphocyte predominance.
  • India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells.
  • CSF ELISA for CRAG (Cryptococcal Antigen).

Treatment

(Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • LAMB (Liposomal Amphotericin-B) and 5-Fluorocytosine (Flucytosine) for 2 weeks
  • Fluconazole is given subsequently for 8-10 weeks.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of progressive weakness that started in his legs after returning from his international trip. He has difficulty climbing stairs, increasing fatigue with normal activities, and mild tingling in his feet. He has a recent history of mild flu-like symptoms, including fever and malaise. On examination, he shows weakness in both lower extremities with reduced muscle tone and absent deep tendon reflexes. Laboratory findings reveal that CSF analysis showed elevated protein with a normal cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Symptoms

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
    • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
    • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
    • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
    • Difficulty in climbing stairs
    • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

questions.text: A 36 y/o patient presents with a 3-week history of headache, low-grade fever, malaise, and confusion. The patient is HIV-negative. O/E, neck rigidity and cranial nerve palsy are affecting the ocular nerves. Lumbar puncture shows elevated WBCs (mainly lymphocytes), high protein, and low glucose levels in the CSF. MRI reveals the following. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Waiting for CSF culture results before initiating treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Starting broad-spectrum antibiotics for bacterial meningitis

options.label: D
options.text: Performing a brain biopsy for a definitive diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Initiating empirical anti-tuberculosis therapy immediately
questions.explanation:
Symptoms and Clinical Features:
  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.
  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.
  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.
  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.
  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.
  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.
  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:
  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).
  • High protein content (1–8 g/L).
  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:


 
  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4–8 weeks, positive in ~50%).
  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10–40%).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:
  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.
 

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions -tuberculoma

Treatment:
  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.
  • Initial drug regimen: isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine.
  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.
  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).
  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32 y/o HIV-positive patient with a CD4+ count of 50/μL presents with fever, headache, nausea, and altered mental status. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows elevated opening pressure. A specific staining test and MRI of the brain reveal the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Staining

Imaging
 

India ink staining of Cryptococcus neoformans

 



 

Gram staining of the CSF reveals clusters of thin-walled, encapsulated yeast forms of various sizes with narrow-based budding consistent with Cryptococcus.

  

MRI showing “Soap bubble appearance” of C.Neoformans

questions.text: A 34 y/o man with a history of HIV/AIDS presents to the ED with complaints of a severe headache, fever, and confusion. His CD4+ T-cell count is 150 cells/μL. Neurological examination reveals right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. An MRI of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate treatment with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin.

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a brain biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Order a chest X-ray to rule out tuberculosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Start empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis.

questions.correct_answer: A. Initiate treatment with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin.
questions.explanation:
Cerebral Toxoplasmosis

About
  • Toxoplasmosis is a common secondary CNS infection in AIDS patients, but its incidence is decreasing due to ART.
  • Occurs typically when CD4+ T-cell counts are <200/μL.
  • Often represents the reactivation of latent T. gondii tissue cysts.
  • Screening for IgG antibodies to T. gondii is recommended at HIV diagnosis.

Pathophysiology
  • Cerebral toxoplasmosis usually arises from reactivation of latent cysts.
  • It is 10 times more common in seropositive patients than seronegative ones.
  • Presents with fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits (e.g., seizures, hemiparesis, aphasia).
  • Cerebral oedema may cause confusion, dementia, lethargy, and progressing to coma.

Investigations
  • MRI typically shows multiple lesions with ring enhancement and surrounding oedema.
  • If MRI is unavailable, double-dose contrast CT may be used.
  • Brain biopsy is definitive but reserved for patients who fail 2-4 weeks of empiric therapy. (Option B ruled out)

Treatment
  • Standard treatment: sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine with leucovorin for 4-6 weeks.
  • Alternatives: clindamycin + pyrimethamine, atovaquone + pyrimethamine, or azithromycin + pyrimethamine + rifabutin.
  • Relapses are common; maintenance therapy (sulfadiazine, pyrimethamine, leucovorin) is recommended if CD4+ T-cell counts <200/μL.
  • Primary prophylaxis: TMP-SMX in patients with CD4+ <100μL and T. gondii IgG.
  • Secondary prophylaxis/maintenance may be discontinued if CD4+ counts >200/μL for 6 months under effective ART.

questions.text: A 42 y/o woman with a history of HIV/AIDS presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness in her right arm and difficulty walking over the past month. She also reports occasional blurred vision and trouble speaking. Her CD4+ T-cell count is 80 cells/μL, and her current ART has been suboptimal. An MRI of the patient is given below. Which of the following findings would be most indicative of the condition affecting this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of JC virus DNA in the CSF.

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid improvement of symptoms after starting a new ART regimen.

questions.correct_answer: A. Presence of JC virus DNA in the CSF.
questions.explanation:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

About
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a serious opportunistic CNS infection in AIDS patients, caused by the JC virus.
  • JC virus is a human polyomavirus; around 80% of adults have antibodies to it, but less than 10% of healthy adults show ongoing replication.
  • PML is the only known clinical disease caused by the JC virus.

Pathophysiology
  • PML lesions start as small foci of demyelination in the subcortical white matter, eventually coalescing.
  • The cerebral hemispheres, cerebellum, and brainstem can be involved.
  • Neurological deficits are multifocal and often protracted. Symptoms include ataxia, hemiparesis, visual defects, aphasia, and sensory deficits.
  • Seizures occur in ~20% of patients.
  • Headache, fever, nausea, and vomiting are uncommon and suggest other diagnoses. (Option C ruled out)

Investigations
  • MRI shows multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions, particularly in the occipital and parietal lobes. (Option B ruled out)
  • Lesions appear hyperintense on T2-weighted images and hypointense on T1-weighted images.
  • JC virus DNA in CSF has a diagnostic sensitivity of 76% and specificity close to 100%.

Treatment
  • No specific treatment exists for PML, but ART has improved survival rates, with some patients surviving >15 years.
  • Before ART, median survival was 3-6 months.
  • ART can cause paradoxical worsening due to immune reconstitution syndrome (IRIS). (Option D ruled out)
  • Only ~50% of patients show neurological improvement with ART.
  • A CD4+ T-cell count >100/μL and maintaining an HIV viral load <500 copies/mL are associated with a favourable prognosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Autoantibody

Target

Effects

Associated Features

AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane

Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness

Most common

MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance

Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of myasthenia gravis presents to the clinic with worsening symptoms, including difficulty in lifting her arms and shortness of breath. On examination, you notice that her eyelids are drooping, and she has double vision. What is the most significant risk associated with her current condition if not addressed promptly?
questions.explanation:
Affected Muscles

Key Features

Ocular muscles

Mimics central eye movement disorders.

Cogan's lid twitch sign

Upper eyelid rises briefly after looking down for some time.

Shoulder girdle muscles

Difficulty in overhead activities like combing hair.

Respiratory muscles

Weakness may cause respiratory failure and aspiration risks.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute muscle weakness, double vision, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of myasthenia gravis and has been experiencing increased fatigue over the past few days. Which of the following clinical features would best help differentiate a myasthenic crisis from a cholinergic crisis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Myasthenic Crisis

Cholinergic Crisis

Cause

Exacerbation of MG

Excessive anticholinesterase use

Symptoms

Severe muscle weakness, respiratory failure

Fasciculations, paralysis, small pupils (Options A & B ruled out)

Other Signs

-

Pallor, sweating, excessive salivation (Option D ruled out)

Diagnosis

Response to edrophonium test (Option C)

Can confirm cholinergic origin

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with known myasthenia gravis presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress. He is diagnosed with a myasthenic crisis. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for immediate management of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

Life-threatening condition due to muscle weakness affecting breathing, leading to respiratory failure.

Triggers
  • Infection
  • Surgery
  • Stress
  • Certain medications

Treatment

Purpose

Details

Respiratory Support

Ensure adequate breathing.

May involve providing oxygen or mechanical ventilation.

Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIg)

Reduce harmful antibody levels.

Helps improve muscle strength by lowering antibodies in the blood.

Plasma Exchange (PLEX)

(Option D ruled out)

Remove harmful antibodies from blood.

Similar to IVIg; generally used when IVIg is ineffective or cannot be tolerated.

Corticosteroids

(Option A ruled out)

Suppress the immune system.

Can improve symptoms but may have significant side effects.

Immunosuppressants

(Option C ruled out)

Suppress the immune response.

Options include azathioprine or mycophenolate mofetil, which help manage the condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness, dry mouth, and absent tendon reflexes. He has a history of smoking. Electrophysiological testing reveals post-tetanic potentiation of motor response to nerve stimulation at a frequency of 20–50/sec. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

A condition causing muscle weakness due to impaired transmission across the neuromuscular junction, similar to myasthenia gravis.

Types
  • Inflammatory
  • Paraneoplastic (associated with underlying malignancies, particularly small-cell lung cancer).

Pathophysiology

Antibodies to presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels impair transmitter release, unlike myasthenia gravis, which involves antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors.

Symptoms
  • Muscle weakness
  • Autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth)

Key Clinical Sign

Absence of tendon reflexes, which may return after sustained contraction of the affected muscle.

Diagnostic Testing

Electrophysiological testing showing post-tetanic potentiation of motor response to nerve stimulation at a frequency of 20–50/sec is indicative of LEMS.

Treatment

Mechanism/Use

3,4-Diaminopyridine

Enhances neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction.

Pyridostigmine

Increases acetylcholine levels, improving neuromuscular transmission.

Immunosuppression

Reduces immune response against voltage-gated calcium channels.

Myasthenia Gravis

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenia Syndrome

   
  • Antibodies to post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors
  • Antibodies to pre-synaptic calcium channels
  • Usually acute or subacute, but can also be chronic.
  • Typically occurs in younger women (20s-30s) or older men (>60s).
  • Gradual onset, often subacute or chronic.
  • Worsens with activity
  • Improves with repetitive use of muscles
  • Decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Rarely associated with cancer
  • Frequently associated with small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is suspected of having myasthenia gravis. The neurologist decides to perform the Tensilon test using edrophonium bromide. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the Tensilon test?

options.label: A
options.text: The effects of the test last for about 10 minutes

options.label: B
options.text: It is a highly specific and sensitive test for myasthenia gravis

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle function typically improves within 30 seconds of injection

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous atropine is unnecessary during the procedure

questions.correct_answer: C. Muscle function typically improves within 30 seconds of injection

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with a history of slowing of movements, frequent falls and forgetfulness. MRI done is as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Progressive supranuclear palsy [PSP]
  • Early onset postural instability - H/O frequent falls + Dementia
  • Tremors - absent (Option B)
  • Defective downward gaze (Option A) + extended posture of body
  • Dystonia: Procerus sign (forehead) + Gunslinger’s gait (flexion at elbow & adduction at upper limb) (Option D)
  • Poor response to levodopa (Option C)
  • MRI: Hummingbird sign

Lewy body dementia [LBD]
  • Parkinsonian features + Visual hallucination + early Dementia
  • Associated REM sleep disorder may be present

Multiple systemic atrophy [MSA]
  • MSA-A: Autonomic instability + (orthostatic hypotension)
  • MSA-C: Cerebellar symptoms + ; MRI- Hot cross bun sign (Pons)

 

Corticobasal syndrome [CBS]
  • Dystonia + myoclonus + alien limb phenomena present alone with other parkinsonian features

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the ER after a fall, initially conscious but rapidly deteriorates following a brief lucid interval. The CT image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Epidural hematoma

Subdural hematoma (Option C ruled out)
  • Biconvex or lens-shaped mass due to the limited ability of blood to expand within the fixed attachment of the dura to the cranial sutures
  • Does not cross suture lines.
  • Typically crescentic in configuration, extending over the cerebral convexity due to the lack of anatomical constraints in the subdural space.

questions.text: In patients presenting with acute ischemic stroke, MRI or CT imaging of a lesion greater than which size is most indicative of a stroke due to large artery atherosclerotic origin?
questions.explanation:
Cardioembolism
  • Comprises patients with arterial blockages likely caused by an embolism originating in the heart.
  • At least 1 cardiac source of an embolus must be identified to consider a possible or probable diagnosis of cardioembolic stroke.
  • Evidence of a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) or stroke in more than 1 vascular territory or systemic embolisms supports a clinical diagnosis of cardiogenic stroke.
  • A stroke occurring in a patient with a medium-risk cardiac source of embolism and no other apparent cause of stroke is categorized as a possible cardioembolic stroke.

Large artery atherosclerosis
  • Patients will exhibit clinical and brain imaging findings indicating either significant (> 50%) narrowing or complete blockage of a major brain artery or branch cortical artery, likely due to atherosclerosis.
  • Presence of intermittent claudication history, TIAs in the same vascular territory, a carotid bruit, or weakened pulses.
  • Lesions in the cortex, cerebellum, brainstem, or subcortical hemispheric infarctions > 1.5 cm in diameter observed on CT or MRI indicate potential large artery atherosclerotic origin.
  • Duplex imaging or arteriography demonstrating more than 50% stenosis of a relevant intracranial or extracranial artery is necessary.

Small vessel occlusion
  • Patients with strokes commonly classified as lacunar infarcts in other systems.
  • Patients should present with 1 of the typical clinical lacunar syndromes and should not exhibit signs of cerebral cortical dysfunction.
  • Patients should have normal CT scan or MRI findings
  • Brainstem or subcortical hemisphere lesion with a diameter of <1.5 cm.

Stroke of undetermined etiology
  • Patient with atrial fibrillation and ipsilateral carotid stenosis of 50%.
  • Traditional lacunar syndrome and ipsilateral carotid stenosis of 50%.

Stroke of other determined etiology
  • Patients with uncommon stroke causes, such as nonatherosclerotic vasculopathies, hypercoagulable states, or hematologic disorders.
  • Patients in this category should exhibit clinical symptoms and CT or MRI findings indicative of acute ischemic stroke, regardless of the size or location of the lesion.
  • Diagnostic tests, such as blood tests or arteriography, should reveal 1 of these unusual stroke causes.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled hypertension presents to the emergency department after suddenly developing a severe headache, vomiting, and one-sided weakness. On examination, he is drowsy with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 10. His blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. CT of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hemorrhagic stroke?
questions.explanation:
Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH)

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)
  • Long standing hypertension produces degeneration of media, breakage of the elastic lamina, and fragmentation of smooth muscles of arteries.
  • Charcot-Bouchard aneurysms: Lipohyalinosis, fibrinoid necrosis of the subendothelium, microaneurysms, and focal dilatations are seen in the arterioles.
  • Common sites of hypertension induced intracerebral hemorrhage are the small penetrating arteries originating from basilar arteries or the anterior, middle, or posterior cerebral arteries.
  • Hypertensive change causes non-lobar intracranial hemorrhage (ICH).
  • Beta 40 Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is an important cause of primary lobar intracerebral bleeding in older adults.
  • Ruptured berry aneurysm (Option A ruled out)
  • Arteriovenous malformation (Option D ruled out)
  • Vasculitis
  • Cerebral artery dissection
  • Dural sinus thrombosis (Option C ruled out)
  • Pituitary apoplexy
  • The risk factors are hypertension, oral contraceptive pills, substance abuse, and pregnancy.

questions.text: A 70 Y/O woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset slurred speech and right-sided facial weakness that resolved after 30 minutes. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her blood pressure on arrival is 160/95 mmHg. She is otherwise stable and has no residual neurological deficits on examination. Based on the ABCD2 score, what is the total score for this patient, and how would her risk of stroke be classified?
questions.explanation:
Age
  • ≥ 60 years = 1 point

Blood Pressure
  • Systolic ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic ≥ 90 mmHg = 1 point

Clinical Features
  • Unilateral weakness = 2 points
  • Speech disturbance without weakness = 1 point

Duration of Symptoms
  • ≥ 60 minutes = 2 points
  • 10-59 minutes = 1 point

Diabetes
  • History of diabetes = 1 point

< 4 points

Low risk of stroke (1% risk of stroke within 2 days)

4-5 points

Moderate risk of stroke (4% risk of stroke within 2 days)

> 5 points

High risk of stroke (8% risk of stroke within 2 days)

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right sided weakness, slurred speech and facial drooping for the past hour. His vital signs are stable and his blood glucose level is within normal range. The attending physician suspects a stroke. What is the most appropriate initial imaging study to confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of stroke?
questions.explanation:
Workup for stroke

Initial Assessment and Stabilization
  • Upon arrival, ensure the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) are stable.
  • Blood glucose levels should be checked quickly to address hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

Determining Stroke Type: Imaging is Key
  • A non-contrast CT scan is the primary imaging modality for differentiating between ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.
  • Clinical features may suggest stroke type, but imaging is essential for confirmation as no clinical finding can definitively differentiate between the two.

Further Investigations: Uncovering the Cause
  • Detailed History and Physical Exam: Consider risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, etc.) and perform a neurological exam to localize the affected brain area.
  • Laboratory Tests: Perform CBC, electrolytes, renal function, blood glucose, lipid profile, coagulation studies, ESR, and ECG (to detect arrhythmias and signs of recent MI).

Visualizing the Cerebral Vasculature: Imaging Techniques
  • CT Angiography (CTA): Assesses cerebral vasculature and identifies blockages/stenosis, but is performed after non-contrast CT has ruled out hemorrhage (not for stroke type differentiation). (Option C ruled out)
  • CT Perfusion Imaging: Assesses blood flow, identifying reduced perfusion and ischemic penumbra.
  • MRI: Provides more detail but takes longer than CT and is not as widely available, thus not the first imaging choice for acute stroke evaluation. (Option A ruled out)
  • MRA: Offers detailed images of blood vessels, similar to CTA.
  • Cerebral Angiography: Gold standard for vessel evaluation, used when other techniques are inconclusive or before endovascular intervention.
  • Ultrasound Techniques: Carotid Duplex Ultrasonography assesses carotid stenosis but is not a first-line acute imaging modality; Transcranial Doppler (TCD) measures blood flow velocity in intracranial arteries. (Option D ruled out)

Tailoring Investigations Based on Stroke Type
  • Ischemic Stroke: Focuses on identifying the source of the blockage (cardioembolic, artery-to-artery embolic, small vessel disease).
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Investigations focus on identifying causes of bleeding (e.g., hypertension, aneurysm, vascular malformation).

questions.text: A 50 year old male patient came to the emergency room with complaints of headache, blurring of vision, altered sensorium, slurring of speech and left sided hemiparesis for 2 hours. He is a known case of diabetes mellitus, hypertension with irregular compliance. His vitals and CT image are given below. What is the most appropriate statement regarding management of this patient? BP - 190/110 mm Hg PR - 92/min SpO2 - 98%

options.label: A
options.text: The head end of the patient bed should be flat to prevent coning of the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Blood pressure of the patient should be reduced to <140/90 with nicardipine.

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate intravenous thrombolysis with rtPA is recommended since the patient is in the window period.

options.label: D
options.text: Heparin should be started immediately to prevent further brain anoxia.

questions.correct_answer: B. Blood pressure of the patient should be reduced to <140/90 with nicardipine.
questions.explanation:
Haemorrhagic stroke

Etiology

  • Accounts for ~10% of all strokes
  • Higher incidence in Asians and blacks.
  • Most common cause - head trauma
  • Other important causes - hypertension, coagulopathy, sympathomimetic drugs (cocaine, methamphetamine), and cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA).
  • Risk factors: Advanced age, heavy alcohol use, low-dose aspirin in asymptomatic individuals.

Clinical features

  • Abrupt onset of focal neurologic deficit, may worsen over 30–90 minutes.
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure (ICP) such as headache, vomiting, altered sensorium, blurring of vision/diplopia,etc
  • Larger haemorrhages can result in drowsiness, stupor or even coma.
  • Specific presentations based on haemorrhage location:
    • Putamen: ipsilateral hemiparesis, slurred speech.
    • Thalamus: contralateral hemiplegia, sensory deficits, possible aphasia.
    • Pontine: deep coma, quadriplegia, pinpoint pupils.
    • Cerebellar: occipital headache, ataxia, vomiting.
    • Lobar: focal headaches, varying neurologic deficits depending on the lobe affected.

Investigations
  • CT scan for acute detection of haemorrhage.
  • Routine blood tests to assess platelet count, prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, and international normalized ratio (INR).
  • MRI may help in identifying underlying causes like arteriovenous malformations (AVMs).
  • Angiography if etiology is uncertain; lumbar puncture is generally avoided due to risk of herniation.

Treatment
  • Acute Management: Assess airway, breathing and control blood pressure.
  • Manage ICP if elevated with elevation of head end of patient bed, administering osmotic agents like mannitol, hypertonic saline, CSF drainage.
  • Correct coagulopathy (e.g., prothrombin complex concentrates for vitamin K antagonists).
  • Prevention focused on controlling hypertension and avoiding illicit drugs.
  • Surgical intervention for cerebellar haemorrhage >3 cm, or if there is significant deterioration.

questions.text: A 68 year old male presents to the emergency department 2 hours after sudden onset of left sided weakness and slurred speech. His blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg, and a non-contrast CT scan shows no hemorrhage. His past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes and he is not on any anticoagulants. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate blood pressure reduction to <140/90 mmHg

questions.correct_answer: A. Intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA)
questions.explanation:
Absolute Contraindications

Relative Contraindications
  • Major trauma, surgery, or head trauma within 3 weeks
  • Prior hemorrhagic stroke
  • Ischemic stroke within the prior 6 months
  • Central nervous system neoplasm
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding within one month
  • Active bleeding
  • Cancer
  • Age > 75–80
  • Transient ischemic attack within 6 months
  • Oral anticoagulant therapy
  • Noncompressible punctures
  • Traumatic resuscitation
  • Refractory hypertension
  • Advanced liver disease
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Active peptic ulcer
  • Pregnancy or within one week postpartum.

Treatment for stroke- ischemic stroke

Immediate Medical Support
  • Stabilize the patient by managing airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs).
  • Manage blood pressure: Permissive hypertension is allowed to maintain cerebral perfusion, but reduce BP if >220/120 mmHg ( reduce BP if >185/110 mmHg- for rtPA). Avoid overly aggressive reduction. (Option D ruled out)
  • Control fever and hyperglycemia.
  • Treat cerebral edema with mannitol or hemicraniectomy if severe.

Restoring Blood Flow: Thrombolysis & Thrombectomy
  • Intravenous Thrombolysis (rtPA): Effective within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.
  • Endovascular Thrombectomy: Best for large vessel occlusions, ideally within 6 hours; can be extended up to 24 hours using advanced imaging.

Preventing Future Strokes
  • Antiplatelet Therapy:
    • Aspirin for secondary prevention, delayed 24 hours post-rtPA or given immediately if rtPA not used. (Option B ruled out)
    • Clopidogrel or ticagrelor may be combined with aspirin for short-term use.
  • Anticoagulation: Recommended for atrial fibrillation but avoided in acute stroke unless cardioembolic source is confirmed after rtPA. (Option C ruled out)

Rehabilitation
  • Early intervention with physical, occupational, and speech therapy helps maximize recovery.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with acute onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech for the past 2 hours. His blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg, and a non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows no evidence of hemorrhage. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, for which he is on warfarin, and a recent gastrointestinal bleed 10 days ago. Which of the following is a contraindication to thrombolysis with rtPA in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Indications and contraindications for thrombolysis

Indications for rtPA in Acute Ischemic Stroke (AIS)
  • Clinical Diagnosis of Stroke: The patient presents with clinical features of acute stroke, confirmed by a neurological examination.
  • No Evidence of Haemorrhage on Imaging: A non-contrast CT scan must exclude hemorrhagic stroke before administering rtPA. (Option D ruled out)
  • Time Window: Administer within 3 hours of symptom onset (FDA); in some regions, the window is extended to 4.5 hours with restrictions. (Option A ruled out)
  • Age: The patient must be 18 years or older.

Contraindications for rtPA in AIS
  • Conditions Increasing Bleeding Risk: Active internal bleeding, bleeding diathesis, recent head trauma (within 3 months), recent intracranial hemorrhage, major surgery in the last 14 days, gastrointestinal bleeding in the past 21 days, recent myocardial infarction. (Option C)
  • Uncontrolled Hypertension: Blood pressure >185/110 mmHg despite treatment increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications. (Option B ruled out)
  • Large Infarct Core: CT scan revealing significant edema in more than one-third of the MCA territory is contraindicated due to the risk of hemorrhage and limited benefit.

Additional Points to Consider
  • Use of Antithrombotic Agents: Concomitant use of anticoagulants requires careful evaluation to avoid increasing bleeding risk.
  • Advanced Imaging: Techniques like CT perfusion or MRI may help identify patients eligible for rtPA beyond the standard time window, even up to 24 hours in some cases, though this approach remains investigational.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents with a headache, seizures and focal neurological deficits. She has a history of oral contraceptive use. MRI venography reveals a filling defect in the cerebral venous sinus as shown in picture below. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT)

CVT is a rare condition caused by a blood clot in the cerebral veins or venous sinuses, obstructing blood flow within the brain.

Causes:

 

CVT can be triggered by:

  • Dehydration
  • Pregnancy
  • Behçet's disease
  • Thrombophilia
  • Hypotension
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Local causes: Paranasal sinusitis, meningitis, subdural empyema, head and eye trauma, facial infections, otitis media, and mastoiditis.

Clinical Presentation:

 
  • Symptoms depend on the affected sinus and often include:
  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Seizures
  • Focal neurological deficits

Diagnosis:

 
  • MR venography is the primary diagnostic tool for CVT, revealing a filling defect in the affected vein or sinus.

Treatment:

 
  • Anticoagulation: Heparin followed by warfarin is the main treatment, even in venous hemorrhage.
  • Endovascular Thrombolysis: May be recommended in some cases.
  • Antibiotics: Required for infections, especially when caused by Staphylococcus aureus (seen in ~10% of CVT cases, particularly in cavernous sinus thrombosis).
  • Comprehensive Management: Includes treating underlying causes and managing complications like persistent raised intracranial pressure.

Types of Sinus Thrombosis

Presentation

Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis
  • Symptoms: Proptosis (eye protrusion), ptosis (drooping eyelid), headache, ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle weakness), papilloedema (optic disc swelling), reduced sensation in trigeminal nerve's first division.
  • Patients are usually febrile and may show bilateral involvement.

Superior Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis
  • Symptoms: Headaches, papilloedema, seizures, can mimic idiopathic intracranial hypertension.
  • Involvement of both hemispheres may lead to progressive motor and sensory deficits.

Transverse Sinus Thrombosis
  • Symptoms: Hemiparesis, seizures, papilloedema, and potential involvement of cranial nerves 9, 10, and 11 if it extends to the jugular foramen.

Cortical Vein Thrombosis
  • Symptoms: Focal cortical deficits such as aphasia, hemiparesis (depending on the affected area), and epilepsy.

questions.text: A 30 year old female who delivered a male baby via C-section owing to eclampsia developed a sudden onset headache, seizures, visual disturbances and altered sensorium 2 days following delivery. MRI showed the following (shown below). What is the likely diagnosis? (CADASIL - Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy)
questions.explanation:
Introduction
  • Neurological disorder characterized by posterior lobe involvement resulting in sudden onset neurological manifestations

Etiology

Hyperperfusion state → Cerebral edema

  • Pre-eclampsia /Eclampsia in the postpartum period
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Drugs: Sympathomimetics (Amphetamine), Cytotoxic (anti-cancer)
  • Renal: AKI, Nephrotic syndrome
  • Autoimmune: SLE, APLA syndrome

Clinical presentation
  • Usually manifests within a week in the postpartum phase
  • Sudden onset headache, seizures.
  • Visual disturbances, altered mentation and other focal neurological deficits
  • Rarely can present with ischaemic symptoms (if present for long duration)

Diagnosis
  • MRI: Hyperintensities + over occipital lobe (and hence the name posterior)

 

Management
  • Anti-hypertensives: first step is to control BP (Target MAP: 130 mmHg)
  • Anti-epileptics: if seizures +

Prognosis
  • Good prognosis, only supportive care required
  • Manifestations are reversible

Differential diagnosis

Reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome (RCVS): (Option A)

  • Presentation: sudden onset severe headache (similar to SAH)
  • Ischemic/hemorrhagic stroke-like presentation
  • Severe new-onset hypertension is usually present
  • Angiography: Non-inflammatory diffuse vascular changes involving all lobes (resembles vasculitis)
  • Treatment: Oral CCBs; recurrence-rare

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with chronic burning pain, numbness, and tingling on the right side of her body not relieved with NSAIDs. The symptoms began 2 months after she suffered a stroke. On examination, she has hyperesthesia and allodynia on the right side. The clinician suspected it to be due to lacunar infarct. What could be the likely site of infarct causing her present symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Cause
  • Lacunar infarct of penetrating branches of PCA (P1 segment)

Clinical features
  • Hemianesthesia affecting one half of body (initially) [Hemisensory loss]
  • Later causing burning pain sensation (during recovery)
  • O/E: Hyperaesthesia, allodynia may be present on the affected side

Treatment
  • Carbamazepine, Gabapentin, TCAs (Tricyclic antidepressants)

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct (affecting penetrating branches) secondary to atherosclerotic occlusion/lipohyalinosis

Risk factors
  • Hypertension: Most common
  • Diabetes
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Smoking
  • Hyperlipidemia

Sites & manifestations
  • Posterior limb of internal capsule (Option B)
  • Pure motor hemiparesis
  • Genu of internal capsule (Option C)
  • Clumsy hand dysarthria lacunar syndrome (facial weakness)
  • Cortical pontocerebellar tract (Option D)
  • I/L ataxia + C/L hemiparesis
  • Ventroposterolateral thalamus (Option A)
  • Dejerine-Roussy syndrome

questions.text: Based on the MRI finding (shown below) , Which of the following criteria and corresponding treatment used in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Chronic neurological disorder characterized by inflammation, demyelination and sclerosis with lesions disseminated over time and space

Pathogenesis

Autoimmune cause:

  • Triggering antigen: Myelin basic protein
  • Antibodies target: Oligodendrocytes

Clinical features
  • U/L Optic neuritis: Positive Uhthoff sign (blurring of vision on heat exposure)
  • Sensory: Positive Lhermitte sign (Flexion at neck → Paraesthesia /shock-like sensation across the spine/back)

Types
  • Relapsing MS: Most common type, usually females, associated with Vit-D deficiency, EBV infection
  • Primary progressive MS: Relatively late onset
  • Secondary progressive MS: Least common

Scoring scale
  • Extended disability scoring scale (EDSS)

Diagnosis
  • Criteria: McDonald’s criteria (Option C)
  • MRI: Dawson’s fingers (demyelination over periventricular areas); lesions dissemination over time & space seen.
  • CSF: Oligoclonal bands +

Treatment
  • Acute: IV Methylprednisolone (Option C)
  • Disease modifying drugs: Ocrelizumab (anti-CD20) > Natalizumab >> Mitoxantrone.
  • Other drugs:
    • IFN-β: least side effects and hence more preferred in chronic disease
    • Fingolimod: SIP-1 Modulator
    • Gatiramer acetate: Polypeptide drug
    • Dimethyl fumarate: Krebs cycle metabolite
    • Miscellaneous : Daclizumab, Almetuzumab, Mitoxantrone

questions.text: Which of the following is false on findings of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Periodic sharp wave complexes on EEG

options.label: C
options.text: Increased intensity in the basal ganglia

options.label: D
options.text: All prion diseases are characterized by spongiform changes

questions.correct_answer: D. All prion diseases are characterized by spongiform changes
questions.explanation:
Electroencephalography (EEG)
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC) (Option A ruled out)
  • These can be either lateralized in earlier stages or generalized in later stages.

MRI findings
  • Increased intensity in the basal ganglia (Option C ruled out)
  • Cortical ribboning (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Describe the lesion given in the MRI below:
Which of the following is a CT finding of Pneumocephalus?
questions.explanation:
Sign

Observation

Mount Fuji Sign

(Option A ruled out)

Accumulation of air in the frontal region, separating the tips of the frontal lobes in a supine patient.

Air Bubble Sign

(Option B ruled out)

Small, round areas of low attenuation (dark regions) representing air pockets within cerebrospinal fluid spaces.

Peaking Sign

(Option C ruled out)

Lack of separation between the tips of the frontal lobes; appears flattened or peaked, indicating increased intracranial pressure.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis on the basis of the CT image given below?
What is the most likely diagnosis on the basis of the MRI image given below?

A 13 year old male patient presented with complaints of poor scholastic performance, history of recurrent seizures since infancy and the following incidental finding on his back. What does the incidental finding denote and probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Shagreen patch and Tuberous sclerosis
questions.explanation:
Tuberous sclerosis (BOURNEVILLE DISEASE)

Pathophysiology

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • Genes involved are TSC1 in chromosome 9 producing hamartin protein and TSC2 is on chromosome 16 producing tuberin protein.
  • Both these proteins play a role in cell growth and cell division. Mutations lead to aberrant activation of mTOR pathway signalling giving rise to various tumours.

Clinical features

  • Classical triad of seizures (epilepsy), low IQ, facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)- EPILOIA
  • Other skin manifestations include shagreen patches, hypomelanotic macules (Ash leaf macules), periungual fibromas (Koenen tumours)
  • Associated with renal angiomyolipomas, cardiac rhabdomyomas (in children)
  • Increased risk of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs)

Treatment

  • Anticonvulsants for seizures
  • mTOR inhibitors (sirolimus or everolimus) for SEGAs and seizure reduction

questions.text: A 75 year old male patient came to the OPD with complaints of recent onset stooping, broad based abnormal gait, short-term memory loss and urge incontinence. On radiological investigation, the following image is obtained. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension

Pathophysiology

  • It usually affects young obese women. Its exact cause is uncertain, but obesity may impair CSF reabsorption, while certain medications like tetracycline and vitamin A are associated.

Clinical features

  • Patients typically present with headaches, diplopia, and transient visual disturbances.
  • Physical signs include papilloedema and possible sixth cranial nerve palsy.

Investigations

  • Brain imaging to rule out structural causes.
  • Lumbar puncture, revealing elevated CSF pressure > 30 cmH2O.

Treatment

  • Weight loss might be beneficial.
  • Medications such as acetazolamide or topiramate may lower intracranial pressure.
  • Repeated lumbar punctures can alleviate headaches, but if vision is threatened, surgical options like optic nerve sheath fenestration or a lumbo-peritoneal shunt may be necessary.

questions.text: A 5 year old female child presented to the casualty with recurrent seizures and left sided hemiplegia. On physical examination, a reddish skin lesion was found since birth over the right side of her forehead involving the right eye, nose and cheek. On CT imaging of the brain, the following picture was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 32 y/o man from a rural area presents with recurrent seizures. He recalls occasionally eating undercooked pork and living in a community with poor sanitation. A brain MRI shows multiple cystic lesions. What is the most likely cause of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Infection by adult Taenia solium tapeworms in the intestines

options.label: B
options.text: Ingestion of T. solium eggs from contaminated food or hands

options.label: C
options.text: Eating undercooked pork containing adult tapeworms

options.label: D
options.text: Migration of larvae from the lungs to the brain

questions.correct_answer: B. Ingestion of T. solium eggs from contaminated food or hands

questions.text: A 12 y/o girl presents with headaches, vomiting, and altered mental status. MRI shows obstructive hydrocephalus caused by multiple cysts blocking cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Neurocysticercosis

Clinical Features

Stages of lesion
  • Seizures: The most common symptom, typically new-onset partial seizures that may generalize.
  • Headaches
  • Hydrocephalus: Caused by cysts obstructing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow, leading to increased pressure.
  • Cognitive and Personality Changes
  • Focal Neurological Deficits (weakness or sensory disturbances)
  • Increased Intracranial Pressure (nausea, vomiting, ataxia, visual deficits, papilledema)
  • Vesicular: Cystic lesions with scolex. The parasite is viable. (Live stage)
  • Colloidal: Cysts degenerate, causing surrounding oedema. (Degenerating stage)
  • Granulonodular: Cysts with less oedema, more solidified. (Degenerating stage)
  • Nodular-Calcified: Parasite is no longer viable. Cysts calcify, with no active inflammation. (Dead stage)

A CT scan of the brain is performed, revealing several ill-defined lesions with surrounding oedema and ring enhancement.
